Rabies infections on the rise in northeastern Thailand

Dr. Tawichai from the 9th Disease Prevention and Control Department revealed on February 9th that in the past few months, the number of rabies infections in northeastern Thailand has increased, with a total of 74 people infected.
So far this year (from last October to September this year), 74 people have tested positive for rabies in the northeastern provinces of Surin and Buriram, with 67 and 7 respectively.
All of them have been vaccinated against rabies in the past.
He also urged people to get vaccinated against rabies with their pets, and not to touch the saliva of animals suspected of being infected.
Rabies can be transmitted from dogs, cats and bats to humans.
If a person is infected and develops symptoms, almost 100% die, but vaccination before symptoms develop can prevent death.

FUJI Preventing Accidents with Removal of Snow  System Development and Testing with Company Vehicles | The Mid-Japan Economist, Economic Information from Aichi, Gifu, Mie, and Shizuoka

FUJI (headquarters: Chiryu city), which handles the installation of electronic parts and the manufacture and sale of robots and machine tools, has started developing a system to prevent "forgetting" children or other items in cars.
The system is equipped with a motion sensor in the car, and when it detects movement, it sends a notification to the phone or chat.
The system is currently being tested in the company's shuttle buses.
To prevent tragic accidents caused by leaving children behind, the company is working to ensure the safety of children.

Currently, two buses are being used for pick-up and drop-off of children at the company's after-school English conversation school for children, "teracoya THANK (TERACOYA SANKU)" in Chiryu City, for testing.
Motion sensors that detect movement by sensing the temperature difference between people and their surroundings are installed in three locations on the ceiling of the vehicle.
When it detects movement after the engine has been turned off and the door has been closed, it automatically sends a warning notification.
By linking the engine and door status and information, we try to prevent false alarms as much as possible.
The warning notification is sent through the cloud.
It can be displayed on a computer or smartphone chat, as well as calling the number that has been registered in advance.
It is possible to register multiple addresses, and measures have been taken to prevent mistakes such as missing someone.
The field test will continue until the end of February.
"During the experiment, we were able to see other issues around the system," said Kanaya Takeshi, chief of the second section of the Innovation Promotion Department.
For example, they were able to pick up various issues related to school buses, such as creating an environment where drivers can concentrate on driving.
"We want to expand the solutions," he said.
The development of a system to prevent abandonment was triggered by a series of accidents involving buses that left passengers stranded across the country.
There was a proposal from employees with children, asking if there was anything they could do to ensure the safety of their children.
The company decided to develop the system by utilizing its know-how in IoT (Internet of Things) and sensors, which it has cultivated through its business in factory automation.
Fujis's parking prevention system is easy to use.
The sensors can be installed simply by pinning them to the ceiling.
Because it can be easily attached to welcome vehicles, we aim to lower the hurdle for adoption.
Going forward, we are considering productization while also considering cooperation with daycare centers and kindergartens.

Valentine's Day-themed chocolate shop that reopens every three years = February 9th, Seibu Fukui store in Fukui city, Fukui Prefecture

Ahead of Valentine's Day on February 14, chocolate prices have risen due to the high cost of raw materials and packaging, but sales of high-priced chocolates for personal use and as gifts for family and friends are doing well.
In Fukui prefecture, retailers and confectionery stores are trying to attract customers by emphasizing local color, luxury, and the quality of ingredients.
Seibu Fukui (Fukui City) opened a special sales area on the 6th floor of the event space on January 25th.
They are selling about 400 brands and 450 types of chocolates, including 10 shops in the prefecture, until the 14th.
Popular items include chocolates and cookies made with local sake, as well as sandwiches with ganache and other fillings.
According to the store manager, the retail price of the products has increased by about 10% compared to the previous year.

This year's trend is that there are many products that stand out with their materials and packaging, and the consumer trend is that they are buying them for themselves and their families, and enjoying comparing them.
Even in the face of rising prices, sales of high-end items are doing well.
→ The average price per piece is 25 yen, up 1 yen due to the high cost of materials.
"We are trying to create a sales space where you can enjoy Valentine's Day as an event," the official said.

Kurafu, a Western confectionery manufacturer and retailer (headquarters: Sakai-shi, Maruko-cho, Ichiban-cho Nakamura-cho), has for the first time introduced its original chocolate series "KISEKI (KISEKI)" developed in collaboration with a long-established French chocolate maker last year, into the Valentine's Day battle.
It has a fruity flavor with a hint of cocoa beans and a reduced bitterness, and is sold in packs of three for 100 yen and packs of nine for 300 yen.

Takuma Takasugi, the executive director and head of the purchasing department of the company, said, "The culture of giving obligatory chocolates is fading, but there is a need for people who want to enjoy a little desire on Valentine's Day. We are trying to increase the value of the product and differentiate it."

The ruins of the castle built in preparation for the battle with Hiraizumi Temple = Fukui Prefecture, Ono City, Ukegahara
It is an area in Ono City, Fukui Prefecture, where the large cow Kakegawa manor once existed.

It is said that the castle of Ukegahara was built in the middle of Mount Kawase, within the district, in preparation for the battle against Hiraizumi Temple, which was in opposition to the manor during the Kamakura period.
It appears in the military chronicle "Taiheiki".
There are no documents left about Ukegahara Castle, but in Taiheiki volume 11, "Echizen Ukegahara Jito Jishou Jiki", the following is written.
Aiwa Ukyo Ryokyo Reiki (Aikawa Yukyo Ryokyo Reiki) was a retainer of the Kamakura shogunate, and was sent to Ono as a Jito.

In 1333, the Rokuhara Tandai agency, which was established by the imperial court to monitor the Kamakura Shogunate and control the western provinces, was defeated by Ashikaga Takauji, and the Kamakura Shogunate was destroyed by Nitta Yoshisada.
When he heard the news that Rokuhara Tandai had been destroyed, Time's family members all fled at once, leaving only about 20 people.
They took advantage of this and attacked the monks of Hiraizumi Temple.
Time Treaty threw his wife and two children into the river, then followed them and committed suicide.

A cat-shaped serving robot is introduced at "Iwase Shio Aged Jingisukan Bon Ton Fukui Station Front Store".
Cute expressions and all, popular with families = Fukui Prefecture, Fukui City, one of the big two in the 2nd district
In Fukui Prefecture, where there is a shortage of workers in the food and beverage industry, there is a growing trend to introduce delivery robots that deliver food to customers' tables.

The robots are helpful for reducing the number of staff needed to run the store, as well as for implementing "contactless" service to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus, and their cute expressions are popular with customers.
From restaurant operators and related parties, there are voices saying, "It will be difficult for local restaurants to secure employees and helpers, and delivery robots will spread even more."
"Jin, Jin, Jingisukan♪".
The robot, which plays light music and displays a cat's face on its screen, smoothly walks around the store while delivering food.
When it arrives at the table, it says, "I've brought your order, nyaa."
"Ishio-Niku Jingisukan Bon Ta Fukui Ekimae Honten" in Fukui City's 2-chome, one of the city's major restaurants, introduced a cat-shaped delivery robot in August 2022.

When a customer brings their order to the robot waiting near the kitchen, they place it on the table and press the table number on the screen, and the robot will autonomously walk to the table and deliver the order.
AI (artificial intelligence) voice function and other features are built in, and the cat face on the screen reacts when touched by the customer, and has a variety of expressions.
The "Bonta Group" that manages the restaurant has introduced the robot in two stores including this one.

President Saito Tatsuyoshi said the reason for introducing it was "labor shortage," and emphasized that it was part of efforts to improve productivity through automation and digital transformation (DX).
The labor cost as a percentage of sales is usually around 30%, but it has been reduced to 21-22% by introducing the robot.
The robots also collect used plates from customers, which is connected to the efficiency of the cleanup process, and "it's fun for families and children, and it's good for promotion," he added.
The Yakiniku and Hot Pot restaurant "Rokuganeyama Fukui-ten" located in Shinpo-cho, Araki, Fukui City also introduced a serving robot in August 2020.
Sonzan Shoten's president, Eifuku, said, "We couldn't find employees or part-timers. We thought it was absolutely necessary to solve the labor shortage."
At the Fukui store, the area where the employee serves and the area where the robot delivers are divided, and it is operated.
The cost of leasing a robot is the same as the salary of one employee.
In order to reduce the number of staff, the store has also introduced a tablet-based ordering system, and is considering the introduction of self-service.
According to the Fukui Labor Bureau, in December 2022, the selection ratio for the restaurant industry's "customer service" was 6.94 times, indicating a high shortage of labor.

The representative of the net system (2-chome, Koguchi Chuo, Fukui City) that sells the meal delivery robot said, "The shortage of labor in restaurants in Fukui Prefecture has become more serious due to the influence of the coronavirus, and there are many inquiries about introducing robots."
"I think that the spread of meal delivery robots will become more common, as it will be increasingly difficult for local outskirt stores to secure employees," said Hoshizaki, the president.
[Opinion] Echizen Town is creating a "Death Note" and distributing it to the citizens who want it.

Last year, the town published a comprehensive "bereavement handbook" that includes information on necessary procedures and writing styles for wills, a list of assets to be passed on, and family trees, and many people came to pick up their own copy.
In various parts of the prefecture, seminars on how to write an obituary and how to prepare for death are held, and "end of life" has become a topic that the citizens are familiar with.
Echizen Town's Ending Note is 35 pages long.

It starts with a review of one's own history, and then goes on to record one's current health and assets, as well as one's wishes for future care, end-of-life medical care, funeral arrangements, and grave sites.
There is also a section for things you want to do in the rest of your life and a place to leave messages for loved ones.
There are 35 pages, but you don't have to fill out every page.
What do you want to write down for your family and the people around you.
The important thing is to clarify your goals.
There are many different types of notebooks available in bookstores and so on, and you can start writing anywhere.
The term "deathbed" was coined in 2009, and it's a job interview.
The Great East Japan Earthquake occurred in 2011, two years after the previous one.
It is said that many people have come to face the reality that "death comes suddenly," and the number of people preparing for their own end and end-of-life has increased.
In the past 30 years equation has changed.
The coronavirus pandemic is still raging around the world.
Prices have risen due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and this winter's electricity prices have soared to unimaginable levels.
On the other hand, wages are not rising in line with the current high prices, and many people are worrying about the future.
On the other hand, the cost of funerals, care and the maintenance of graves, which used to be shared with family and friends, is now a burden for many.
And the dilemma of living longer, but with a greater risk of dementia and care needs as we age.
It is important to remember that these social anxieties are also growing against the backdrop of the transient nature of death.
Anyway, no one wants to overburden their partner or children.
"Dying with dignity" is a popular keyword in the Ending Note, but it can't be left to individuals alone.
Rather than writing down hopes and wishes in secret, I want to talk to my family about it and prepare calmly.

No masks needed for children and teachers at graduation ceremony = February 10, Toda City, Saitama Prefecture
On February 10, the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology decided that children should not wear masks at graduation ceremonies.

"It's difficult to keep students apart at a large school, and we're struggling with how to deal with it. There are students who feel anxious about taking off their masks," said the principal of a large middle school.
After news reports about mask-wearing at graduation ceremonies, the topic is also being discussed among teachers.

On the other hand, the principal of one elementary school said, "If the government decides that they should not wear masks, they will not wear them. It is not realistic to respond to anything other than singing."

In this graduation ceremony, some schools have allowed students who have been self-isolating to participate, and some have resumed the graduation song. Some schools in the prefecture are also exploring ways to relax countermeasures.

In the prefecture, prefectural high schools are planning to hold their graduation ceremonies in early to mid-March, while public elementary and junior high schools are planning to hold their ceremonies in mid-March.

The prefectural board of education and city/town boards of education are waiting for an official notice from the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology before deciding how to proceed.
There have also been calls for caution over the Ministry of Education's decision to make masks mandatory for all school education activities from the new term this spring.

"Suddenly, children will be confused if we start doing without masks. It's natural that more children will start taking them off after we first decided to allow them to wear them," said a principal of an elementary school.

On February 10, the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology decided that masks would no longer be required in school education activities from April, in line with the government's new guidelines on mask use.
Masks will not be required in singing, physical education, or club activities.

For the 2022 academic year, we will require infection prevention measures in accordance with the current health management manual, and we will inform the Education Committee and schools of the details and precautions for April and beyond.

For graduation ceremonies at elementary, junior high, and high schools, as well as universities, during the 2022 academic year, graduates, teachers, and students attending the ceremony will be required to wear masks as a general rule, while taking measures such as ventilation.

NPO corporation "Kokoro no Hibiku Honshu・Henshusho" self-published the book "Dear Prime Minister, a beloved breakwater for life", from Tōjinbō
We have published our 10th book, "Dear Prime Minister, A Lifeline from Tōjinbō"
All over the country, newspapers have taken up the story, and many readers have sent in their comments.

The purpose of publishing this book is to share the "social and structural" environment that is the cause of suicide in Japan, as heard directly from those who have planned suicide, and to create a society where everyone can live with "a sense of belonging".

We have been patrolling the cliffs of Tōjinbō, a famous suicide spot in Fukui Prefecture, for 18 years and 10 months to prevent suicide, and have been continuing our efforts to find and protect suicidal people and help them start over.

This book is a summary of the problems we have heard from the 784 people (2/6 currently) we have protected so far, and we are presenting the following seven items to the Prime Minister as necessary measures to prevent suicide.
(1) Suicide prevention activities are "life-saving" activities.
(2) Behind suicide, there are "human rights violations" piled up.
(3) Suicides are victims of social and structural organized crime.
(4)Administrative agencies are treating citizens who live outside their jurisdiction as "outsiders" and treating them coldly.
(5) Mental health patients are drugged and treated as "accidents" even if they commit suicide.
(6) The "duty of care" for suicide hotspots is being forgotten and commercialism is taking over.
(7) The teachings of new religious organizations are fraudulent and threatening, as they cannot be scientifically proven and they threaten future curses and offerings.
The religious organizations that are committing these "fraud and extortion" crimes should be named and excluded.

So, we have received many comments from readers of this book, such as "I was impressed by the strong mentalities of those who are involved in this activity", "The former policeman is a true policeman", "He is a bodhisattva who lives helping others even though he is not related to them", and so on, and we would like to introduce one of the comments here.
I would look at the pictures in the newspaper and think "what must they have been thinking..." and tears would come to my eyes.
I hear that people are committing suicide due to being cornered by the coronavirus.
It is a VERY SAD "life" really.
Everyone is unique.
I hope it will be a society where we can live happily with the lives we have been given.
I have a great deal of respect and gratitude for the staff who are working so hard to help those who are feeling the unbearable pain of wanting to die.
I think this is a really tough job, both physically and mentally, and I hope you can look after yourselves and continue to speak out.
Thank you very much.
So bring on the horror, the fear and alarm.
I hope that you, as a reader, will become a gatekeeper for your area.

Shimada Keiji-san, who photographs capybaras every week and posts them on SNS = February 1st, at the indoor facility "Happijan" in Asuwa Park Amusement Park in Fukui City, Fukui Prefecture
There is a man in Fukui City who takes pictures of the capybaras at the indoor facility "Happijan" in Asuwa Park amusement park every week and posts them on Instagram.
In the posts, there are many thumbnail images of yawning with big mouths showing teeth, and sleeping and yawning with their mouths open.

The man is Shimada Keiji (38), a company employee who lives in the city.
He began posting on social media in March 2021.
Capybaras are the world's largest rodents, and they can swim with their fingers just above the water.
Hapisyan has been open for 18 years and currently has three capybaras, one male and two females, and visitors can observe them up close and feed them.
Mr Shimada first learned about capybaras about 5 or 6 years ago.
He was shocked when he saw a video of a capybara relaxing in a hot spring and asked, "What kind of animal is this?"
He was drawn in by their human-like expressions and mannerisms.
After that, I heard that they were being raised in Happijan, and I was looking forward to being able to see them up close.
He started taking photography seriously about 3 years ago, when he bought a single-lens reflex camera.
I use it to capture the cute appearance of capybaras, and I don't miss any opportunities to take shutter shots of their bodies shaking and splashing water like a drill.
He has posted around 830 photos on Instagram and says, "I'm glad I took these."
When you pass by, you'll notice Shimada-san, and the male Yamato will come close and make a "kyuru kyuru" sound.
"They're cute and I'm happy," says Shimada, who has also grown to love capybaras.
Through SNS, I enjoy exchanging with capybara lovers all over the country and showing off our best shots every month.
Shimada, who also visits zoos in nearby prefectures to see capybaras, smiled and said, "I'll continue to take pictures and share them from my home, Mount Asuwa."

[Toba] On the 10th, Toba City announced that a total of 600,000 yen was mistakenly paid to 11 households in child-rearing support special allowances (other than child-rearing allowances) for the Reiwa 3rd year.
The city is asking the recipients to apologize and explain the circumstances, while also asking them to take the necessary steps to return the money.
The city discovered the error when the guardians of the children who received the payments in January of Reiwa 5 pointed out the past payments on January 27th.
When they confirmed the entirety of the recipients for that year, they found that 11 households had received double the amount they were supposed to on July 20th of that year.
The city pays 50,000 yen per child under high school age for households that do not pay resident tax.

The city had been receiving data from a contracted accounting company that had extracted the eligible children, but an employee mistakenly thought that the high school students were included and added them to the data, resulting in double payments.
The official in charge of the city's childcare support room said, "We will take this seriously and make every effort to prevent a recurrence by checking the data again and restoring trust."

On the 10th, the prefecture and Ichinoseki city announced that the Bellino Hotel Ichinoseki (Yamazato, Ichinoseki) had been inappropriately using the subsidy for the accommodation fee subsidy program for tourists for about a year from October 2021.
When people who were not eligible for the discount stayed, the staff would lend them their name and apply the discount.
In addition, it was confirmed that there were many cases in which employees used the accommodation in a way that did not meet the purpose of "stimulating tourism demand".

The total amount of 7,231,000 yen, which was inappropriately used and received, will be returned by the hotel by the 6th of this month, including the results of the hotel's own investigation and the amount received by the prefecture and the city.
The misuse of subsidies was in the prefectural lodging discount "tourism support project" and the city's emergency lodging support discount "Ichinoseki lodging support discount".

The period was from October 18, 2021 to October 10, 2022 (October 30, 2022 for the Ichinoseki accommodation subsidy), and as a result of the investigation, 95 cases of inappropriate use were found, totaling 5,870,000 yen, and 1,239 cases of inappropriate use that did not meet

The subcontractor of the prefecture's project was in the process of settling the accounts, and it was confirmed that the same person was both the user of the accommodation discount and the person in charge of accepting the hotel.

At Mizusawa Racecourse in Odashimachi, Natori City, a ceremony was held in front of the horse statue (Barekishin), attended by about 50 people, including employees, horse owners, jockeys, and stablemen from the racecourse, as well as Odashima Kiyoshi, the head of the Odashima family.

Introduction to pioneers of plant research, including data on Mount Hayachine, at the city's comprehensive cultural property center exhibition [Hanamaki] | Iwanichi Online | Iwate Nichinichi Shimbun

An exhibition that introduces the people who built the foundation of research on the alpine plants of Mount Hayachine, known as a treasure trove of alpine plants, will be held at the Hanamaki City General Cultural Asset Center in Ohasama-cho until the 12th.
The exhibition has collected 124 items, including valuable specimens collected by the pioneers, to introduce the footprints of the pioneers involved in the research of Mount Hayachine plants.

The study of plants on Mount Hayachine began with the arrival of Russian plant researcher Karl Johann Maximowicz (1827-91) during the end of the Edo period, and with Chonosuke Sugawa (1842-1925), a native of Zaho-cho who collected plants under the guidance of Maximowicz.
Maximovitch, who was not allowed to freely walk around the country as a foreigner, asked Nukawa to collect plants and continued research for three years, based in Yokohama and Nagasaki.

After Maksimovitch returned to Russia, Nukawa continued to support his research, and the two were connected by the discovery of the unique plants of Mount Hayachine, such as "Himekosazura", "Nambutouuchisou", and "Miyamayamabukishouma".

After that, modern botanist Makino Tomitaro (1862-1957) published "Bistorta hayachinensis", "Cobanotsumecksa", "Draba japonica" based on the specimens collected by local researchers in 1903 (Meiji 36), and in 1905 (Meiji 38), he discovered and named "Arenaria katoana"
From the exhibits, we can see that many researchers have discovered precious alpine plants.

In addition, the article introduces Sugimura Matsuzo (1874-1948), who was a teacher at Hanaoka Elementary School and conducted plant research while accompanying the survey for the preservation of natural monuments in 1927 (Showa 2), and Tamakawa Shichiro (1914-88), who was an apprentice at the Mount Ōhasama Museum and participated in the

Yoshida Toshihide, a researcher at the same center, says, "There are many layers of research and connections behind the names of each plant on Mount Hayachine. We can connect researchers from all over the country through these connections."

The exhibition is divided into four chapters. The first chapter is about the belief and history of Mount Hayachine, the second chapter is about German geologists who built the foundation of Japanese geology, such as Edmund Naumann (1854-1927), and the third chapter is about the features of Mount Hayachine from the perspective of geology.

On the Kitakami Line between Fujinomiya and Horokawa, trains will be running on both lines from the start of service until around 9:00 am, and some trains between Kitakami and Fujinomiya will be suspended.

The Ofunato Line will run trains on the up and down lines between Ichinoseki and Kesennuma from the start until around 5:30pm, and the Kamaishi Line will run trains on the down line between Sendai and Kamaishi from the start until noon, and on the up line from the start until 11:00am.
The Tohoku line will also suspend some trains on the up and down lines.
The plan may change depending on the weather conditions.

[Gaziantep (Turkey) in common] According to the authorities of Turkey and neighboring Syria, where the epicenter of the earthquake was located in the southern part of Turkey, the number of confirmed deaths has reached 9,000, exceeding 21,000 in both countries.
The rescue of survivors from collapsed buildings and other structures is becoming increasingly difficult as time passes in the freezing cold.
Search and rescue efforts are being carried out in the disaster area.
On the 9th, the United Nations delivered aid to the Syrian northwestern province of Idlib for the first time since the earthquake on the 6th, crossing the Turkish border.
Idlib province is the last bastion of anti-government rebels in Syria's civil war, and there were fears that international aid would not reach the area.
Rescue efforts are ongoing in both countries, but are hampered by the difficult conditions.
Many are feared buried under the rubble, and the death toll is expected to rise.
According to the authorities, 17,674 people have been confirmed dead in Turkey.
The disaster, which has killed more than 3,000 people in Syria, is the deadliest since the 1999 earthquake in northwestern Turkey that killed more than 17,000 people.

Re-energizing and setting goals at Amami Airport, the second decarbonization promotion council meeting | Society & Economy | Naha Shimbun
Amami Airport decarbonization promotion council = On the 9th, Kasaricho, Amami City

The "Amami Airport Decarbonization Promotion Council" (Chairman: Ando Tatsuo, Kagoshima Prefecture Ōshima Subprefecture Construction Division Chief, Council Members: 13), which was established to reduce greenhouse gas emissions at Amami Airport (Amami City, Satsurigi-cho), held its second meeting at the airport on the 9th.
All members, including online participants, attended the meeting.
They discussed setting goals for decarbonization and exchanged opinions on introducing solar power as a renewable energy source.

The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism has set a target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from all airports by 46% or more from the previous year (13 years ago) by 2050, aiming for "carbon neutrality" with zero emissions.
In response to this, the council held its first meeting in November last year, and is aiming to be the first among the other six airports in the prefecture to draw up plans.
The second meeting was held in the same manner as the first meeting, with the exception of the opening remarks, and was non-public.
After the meeting, Ando, the chairman, who responded to the interview, said that the meeting confirmed the amount of greenhouse gas emissions from the airport.
The discussions were aimed at setting targets and introducing renewable energy in line with the guidelines set by the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism, he said.
According to the handout, the CO2 emissions from the airport's equipment and vehicles in the base year of 2013 were 1,476 tons (excluding aircraft).

Of these, the emissions from lighting and air conditioning in seven facilities, including the terminal building, account for about 90% at 1,321 tons, followed by 84 tons of aviation lighting and 71 tons of airport vehicles.
The council discussed reducing the emissions of these facilities and vehicles.
Ando said, "We are at a crossroads now. The direction of the committee members is the same, and we want to make sure we have a solid report on the interim report."
Going forward, the third meeting will be held to discuss the interim report, the fourth meeting will be held to discuss the final report, and a promotion plan will be formulated.
Kasama Real Estate Office Opens to Attract People to the Island  Recruiting people who want to live there | Society & Economy | Naha Shimbun
Opening event to deepen understanding of "sakasama real estate" through talk sessions = August 8th, famous town

[Okinawa-cho General Office] An event to visualize the thoughts of people who want to try borrowing empty houses and shops, and to recruit landlords, for the real estate web service "Sakasama-fudosan" (literally, "hanging land") was held on the 8th at the well-known community space "entaku" in Chinatown.
The operator explained the service in a talk session.
Okinobu (Hokkaido, Rishiri district), which operates the branch, said, "If we can get people to come to Okinoshima through this initiative, we can create a flow of people to the island."

Sakasama real estate is the opposite of the usual real estate process, where it opens up information about people who want to rent and contacts the landlord, and if they agree, they contract with each other.

On―Co Co., Ltd. (headquarters in Mie Prefecture), which operates the service, started the service in June 2020 as a real-world experiment to discover vacant houses and build relationships through them.
This is the seventh branch to be opened, and the first in Kyushu.
It would not have been the first time nationally.
About 20 people, including On-Co staff and staff from the town office, the ward office, and the town hall, as well as local residents, participated in the event.

Okubo, the representative director, explained the background of the branch office opening, saying, "I thought that if we could actively invite people from outside the island to use vacant houses and shops, the town and the island would become more vibrant."
"We want to help connect people who have property on the island or want something with us to advance our efforts one property and one person at a time," he said.

Mizutani Takashi, the representative of On―Co, pointed out the importance of discussing how to fill empty houses one by one, how to make the local community grow, and who to invite to the area as criteria.
"The more people connect with each other, the more information they can gather," he said, calling for participation in discussions with islanders and cooperation in providing information.

I experienced two failed attempts at front door picking 8 years ago and have been taking countermeasures against theft since then.
This time, it's a replacement for the camera I bought 8 years ago.
Previously, I was using an infrared illuminator with a range of 30m (from another company).
This product, as written by others, can identify faces at night from 5m away.

If you are looking for a camera that can do face recognition other than security, you may be disappointed with night time shooting but this is the best at this price!
I use it for security, but I don't need facial recognition.
Because it can't make out masks or face coverings (especially at night).
Professional burglars (thieves) know security cameras.
It seems to be able to distinguish between small, high-performance cameras and recording.
Otherwise, the non-pros get into trouble.
That said, recent burglars are bold and clever, so don't rely on cameras alone, but use a variety of security measures.
For example, you can buy a white solar LED garden light for 1,500 yen at a home center (the latest ones are very bright, 6 LEDs).
It doesn't need electricity as it's solar powered, but it won't light up until morning in winter, so I've also got a 3-way 100V PIR sensor light.
With this combination, I was able to secure a detection range of 30m.
Also, for daytime security, I think a cover is necessary if you feel that the small size of the camera might reduce the deterrent effect.
I have a "24 hour security camera in operation" sticker on the window.
It's an original product from the security camera manufacturer I used to use.
I find the ones made by the manufacturer work better than the ones you can buy at the hardware store.
I stick them on the likely routes a thief would take to avoid being caught on camera.
So that means this time, I wanted a sticker~.
I also found the instructions for setting up the camera on the net confusing, so I'm giving it a minus for that.
I'll add any issues I have after installing and setting it up.

Persona songs are still good!
I've reached the ED of Persona 3.
I played up to 5.
Persona 4 is completed on vita.
The things you can do are the same as in the previous Persona 4.
It feels shorter than the previous one because there's no story.
The music is still great!
Just listening to it makes me feel better!
The characters from Persona 3 were HD for the first time, so I was moved when I saw them.
Somehow, Junya looks like an ikemen (lol) Persona 5 is already beautiful, so it's fresh... If you think that way, then 3 is a better deal.
As for the music, I felt that 5 was easier to play than 3.
Persona 3 is blue-based, so the backgrounds were hard to see.
5 has bright colors like red and yellow as the main colors, so they are easy to see even if they blend with the background.
It has a lot of assist functions, so I think even people who are bad at music can enjoy it.
For audio experts, turning on the challenge function may make it a game that is hard to beat.
The triple pack includes the soundtrack, but it’s not just a bonus, it’s a full 4-disc set, so if you like Persona’s music, I recommend this.
